newsitem.title: LEBANON: Israeli air raid heightens fear in Lebanon.
newsitem.headline: Israeli air raid heightens fear in Lebanon.

text.p: Israeli helicopters rocketed suspected Hizbollah targets after a clash with the pro-Iranian group in south Lebanon on Friday, heightening fears that the Jewish state might mount a broad military offensive.
Lebanese security sources said the helicopters fired two rockets into Jabal al-Rafi in Iqlim al-Toufah ridge, a Hizbollah bastion north of Israel's south Lebanon occupation zone.
There was no immediate word on casualties.
Hours earlier Israeli soldiers ambushed members of the group who had infiltrated the Israeli-held border zone, killing one guerrilla, Israeli security sources said.
Hizbollah claimed responsiblity for the infiltration and said its guerrillas ambushed an Israeli patrol, wounding several soldiers.
The helicopter attack was the first Israeli air raid on Lebanon in more than a month. On August 8, Israeli planes blasted Hizbollah targets in the eastern Bekaa Valley.
The Israeli army said two helicopters were sent in after Israeli soldiers spotted "suspicious figures" in Jabal al-Rafi.
"The helicopters fired at a building in which the terrorists apparently were hiding," the army added in a statement.

A senior Lebanese Foreign Ministry official said on Thursday Beirut was taking seriously a warning by Israel's proxy militia in south Lebanon of widescale Israeli retaliation if Hizbollah guerrillas stepped up their attacks on Israeli troops.
Lebanese Foreign Minister Faris Bouez described the warning in remarks published on Friday as blackmail aimed at forcing Lebanon to accept the Jewish state's peace proposals.

"We reject this blackmail and threats which are aimed at dragging Lebanon to accept vague Israeli proposals," Bouez was quoted as saying in Syria's official press after his talks with Syrian President Hafez al-Assad on Thursday.

Israel launched a bloody 17-day blitz it called Operation Grapes of Wrath against Hizbollah guerrillas in Lebanon in April, killing 200 people after tit-for-tat bombardments of civilian areas by the two sides.

An April 26 understanding that ended the onslaught banned both parties from firing from or at civilian targets on both sides of the Israeli-Lebanese border. However, it did not rule out guerrilla attacks on Israeli troops inside the buffer zone.

The Israeli sources said that before Friday's air raid an Israeli patrol fired machineguns and rocket-propelled grenades at guerrillas in Wadi Slouki in the western sector of the 15-km (nine-mile) wide zone.

In Beirut, Hizbollah said in a statement: "A group of resistance fighters infiltrated into the Wadi Slouki valley and ambushed Israeli soldiers patrolling on foot at 7:30 a.m. with machineguns and rocket-propelled grenades, inflicting a number of injuries among them."
The statement made no mention of the killing of a Hizbollah guerrilla, which was confirmed in the Israeli army statement.

"A Hizbollah terrorist was killed by Israeli army fire and it is possible that another terrorist was hit in a clash between an Israeli army force and a Hizbollah squad in the central sector of the security zone in south Lebanon. There were no Israeli casualties," the army statement added.
Later, Israeli gunners shelled targets north of the zone, the Lebanese security sources added.
Hizbollah, fighting a guerrilla war to oust the Jewish state from south Lebanon, has killed 18 Israeli soldiers this year.
